title: Recycle Bottles & Cans
impact: Americans use 2,500,000 plastic bottles every hour, and most of them are thrown away! In 2006, Americans drank about 167 bottled drinks each and only recycled about 23% of the bottles. That leaves 38 billion water bottles in landfills, and plastic bottles take 700 years before they begin to decompose.

title: Re-brew Tea Leaves/Bag
impact: If you‚Äôre an artisan tea lover, you may spend a lot of money on tea every year. It‚Äôs a no-brainer that you‚Äôll save a lot of money if you steep your tea multiple times, and you'll be helping the environment at the same time!

title: Turn Off Unnecessary Lights
impact: Leaving a single 100 watt lightbulb on for a day uses 8.64 megajoules of energy, so leaving multiple lights on can add up to a lot of energy usage. Turning off all of your houselights before going to sleep greatly reduces this energy usage, helping both the environment and your energy bill.

title: Power Down Computers
impact: According to Energy Star, turning off 1,000 computer monitors will save 200,000 kWh per year. Setting your computer to sleep mode reduces energy consumption by at least 87%. To further reduce your computer‚Äôs energy consumption, turn it off when not in use; enable the Power Management feature; and don‚Äôt use a screen saver.

title: Use Scratch Paper
impact: Reusing paper can save your organization money and can also help with several environmental problems. Of all trees harvested for industrial use, 42% go to making paper. Unfortunately, the degradation of forests is only part of the story. The pulp and paper industry is also the largest industrial user of water, the biggest water polluter, and the third largest emitter of global warming pollution in most industrialized nations.

title: Wash Clothes with Cold Water
impact: Water heating consumes about 90% of the energy it takes to operate a clothes washer. Unless you‚Äôre dealing with oily stains, washing in cold water will generally do a good job of cleaning.

title: Opt For an Email Receipt
impact: Many stores and resturants now give you the option to have a digital receipt emailed to you. This will help eliminate some of your paper waste (and you won't lose any important receipts)!

title: Shower Under 5 Minutes
impact: The average American's shower lasts for 8 minutes and uses about 17 gallons of water. Taking shorter showers will help decrease your water usage!

title: Set your thermostat to 68¬∞ F
impact: You can save as much as 10% a year in heating and cooling costs by turning back thermostats 7 ‚Äì 10 degrees Fahrenheit for eight hours a day. Constantly raising or lowering the temperature throughout the day or forgetting to set it to the proper temperature can actually cost you more over time.

title: Get a Friend to Sign Up for EcoBud!
impact: Tell your friends about EcoBud, and help more people start living sustainably! Get points for up to 5 friends, but the more the merrier!

title: Bring Reusable Bag
impact: Firstly, swapping disposable bags for reusable bags will save you money! Recycling plastic bags often costs more than it is worth, so many recycling facilities will not accept them, leaving them to end up in landfills. Disposable plastic bags are often flimsy and break easily, whereas reusable bags are more durable and can carry more without breaking.

title: Do a Full Load of Laundry
impact: Let‚Äôs look at some actual numbers. A typical household can save 3,400 gallons of water a year by running full laundry loads instead of half loads, according to the U.S. Department of Energy. Given a national average of $1.50 per 1,000 gallons of water, that‚Äôs an annual savings of $5.15 from just the water in the washing machine over the course of a year.

title: Use Eco-friendly Cleaning Products
impact: Shifting to eco-friendly cleaning products and methods is a sure way of ensuring that we live in healthy, clean and toxin-free environments. You can probably even find something around your house to use! You can even make your own. For example make a multi-purpose cleaner with  ¬º cup of white vinegar, 1 tbsp baking soda, 1 litre of hot water, & ¬Ω a lemon.

title: Hang Your Clothes to Dry
impact: Hanging your clothes to dry instead of using a clothes dryer reduces your energy use. And while you're at college, it means you won't have to pay for dryer use!

title: Buy Bulk Groceries
impact: Smaller portioned groceries and snack packs use more packaging per serving than their bulk alternatives. Buying your popular groceries in bulk will help reduce the amount of packaging needed. You can also make your own snack packs by using small tupperware containers!

title: Use Reusable Straw
impact: The United States goes through 500 million plastic straws every day, and that plastic severely impacts the environment: straws make up about 7% of the total plastic waste humans produce. It‚Äôs no surprise then that major rivers all around the world carry some 1.15-2.41 million tons of plastic into our seas each year. But you can make an effort to reverse this harrowing trend by moving toward eco-conscious, reusable straws!

title: Compost food scraps
impact: When food waste is thrown into landfills, it generates methane, a potent greenhouse gas. By composting wasted food and other organics, methane emissions are significantly reduced.

title: Buy Used Books
impact: Producing and retailing a new book generates 8.85 lbs of CO2. Shipping a book 2,132 miles by ground uses just 1.7 lbs of CO2. When possible buy used and buy local!

title: No Food Waste from Meal
impact: Reducing food waste is environmentally important, because it keeps food out of landfills. It makes economic sense on a small scale, by lowering household food bills and at the large scale by reducing disposal costs for restaurants, processors and farmers. Finally, reducing food waste is socially important when the rescued food is redirected to emergency food providers working to eliminate hunger in our communities.

title: Vegetarian for the Day
impact: Reducing consumption of meat can help contain production of greenhouse gases that impact climate change. It can also help lessen the demand for precious environmental resources such as land, water, and energy. If you can't pass up the Hoch's Monday steak night, choose a different day of the week to go meatless.

title: Buy Second-Hand Clothes
impact: Opting to purchase your clothing second-hand (and avoiding fast-fashion) reduces your carbon footprint. You'll also save lots of money! Make sure you wash thouroughly!

title: Donate Old Clothes & Items
impact: Donating your gently used items to non-profit organizations like GoodWill will help extend the item's life. You are not only helping to reduce our reliance on single-use products and fast fashion, but you are also likely helping those less fortunate than you!

title: Replace a Lightbulb with an LED One
impact: LED lightbulbs use only about 15% of the energy that incandescent bulbs of the same brightness use. Replacing incandescent bulbs with LED bulbs can therefore save hundreds of megajoules of energy each year!

title: Read Environemntal Research Paper/Article
impact: There are millions of people out there working on all types of fascinating environemntal researches. Grab a cup of your favorite beverage + pick out one or two of the articles and researches every week + spend some time exploring progresses humans are having in understanding our ecosystem!

title: Learn About an Environmental Initiative
impact: Local initiatives are a really great way to get involved with environmental issues, whether it is increasing access to bike paths within a city or campaigning to have stricter laws passed about ____.

title: Apply for a Career in Sustainability
impact: You can go forward and make a positive impact in a way that is unique to your skillset.

title: Recycle E-Waste
impact: Only 10 percent of cell phones are recycled in the United States and most Americans get new cell phones every 12 to 18 months. This is creating more and more electronic waste and with the lack of responsible recycling, the environmental issues of e-waste are continually increasing. Computers and most electronics contain toxic materials such as lead, zinc, nickel, flame retardants, barium, and chromium. Specifically with lead, if released into the environment can cause damage to human blood, kidneys, as well as central and peripheral nervous systems. When e-waste is warmed up, toxic chemicals are released into the air damaging the atmosphere.

title: Take an Environmental Analysis Class
impact: The 5Cs have tons of classes focused on climate change! Interested in learning more about the topic? Register for one next semester!

title: Attend the Sus + X Events!
impact: We have some awesome sustainability speaker events and documentary viewings/discussions coming up!
